title: Selecting Classes
text:
Second Prompt
Please provide me information regarding the difficulty and the course quality ratings of the courses you provided me with in the previous response.
Many of the courses previously recommended at the University of Pennsylvania are regarded as high quality, though some require substantial reading and a strong analytical approach. Here is an overview of student-reported difficulty and course quality ratings for the main courses mentioned:

PSCI 1601: Political Ideas: Left, Right, and Center

Difficulty: Generally viewed as moderately challenging, depending on the professor and student‚Äôs background in political philosophy. Similar courses in the department are noted for fair grading but substantial reading and writing requirements.[1][2]
Course Quality: Students praise these courses‚Äô relevance and engaging teaching, although not always the easiest electives. Classes like PSCI 230 (‚ÄúPublic Opinion and American Democracy‚Äù), taught by Michelle Margolis, are specifically highlighted as ‚Äúvery informative, super interesting‚Äù with fair grading and significant workload.[2]



LGST 1010: Law and Social Values

Difficulty: The course is described as rigorous, especially in sections taught by professors who model exams after law school hypotheticals, requiring careful reading and novel application of course concepts. Still, it is foundational for those interested in law and considered manageable with strong analytical and writing skills.[3][4]
Course Quality: LGST 1010 is seen as well-structured, with a reputation for teaching students to ‚Äúthink like a lawyer‚Äù even at the undergraduate level. Course reviews highlight its engaging approach to legal theory and excellent preparation for more advanced legal coursework.[5][4]



HIST 1119: History of American Law to 1877

Difficulty: This seminar-style class is frequently reported as enjoyable and rewarding, with a workload that includes assigned readings, participation, and essay-based assessments. Students find it possible to earn strong grades with consistent work.[6][7][8]
Course Quality: HIST 1119 receives enthusiastic feedback, with students describing the professor as engaging and the material as ‚Äúthoroughly enjoyable.‚Äù It blends legal and historical analysis in ways that appeal to those interested in both fields.[9][6]



Summary Table








Course Code
Difficulty Level
Course Quality

Moderate (reading/writing heavy)
Relevant, engaging theory, fair grading, strong reputation[2][1]

All three courses provide solid preparation for law school or advanced study by fostering analytical, research, and critical writing skills. Each requires consistent effort but is widely praised for quality instruction and engaging content.[2][3][6]

title: First Car Reccomendation
text:
What reccomendations would you have for first cars for a high school kid who just got their license.
For a high school kid who just got their license, the best first car recommendations focus on safety, reliability, affordability, and ease of driving. Here are some solid options:



Look for cars with good crash-test ratings and modern safety features like airbags, anti-lock brakes, and stability control.
Avoid high-performance or overly large vehicles that might be harder for new drivers to handle.





Choose brands known for lasting a long time without expensive repairs‚ÄîToyota, Honda, Hyundai, and Mazda are often top picks.
Older used cars from these brands can be very cost-effective while still reliable.





A used car in good condition around $5,000-$10,000 is often a smart choice for teens.
Economical vehicles that don‚Äôt guzzle gas are great for keeping ongoing costs low.





Smaller cars or compact SUVs that are easy to maneuver and park help new drivers build confidence.





Toyota Corolla or Camry (used, reliable, good safety)
Honda Civic or Accord (dependable, affordable maintenance)
Mazda3 or Mazda CX-3 (fun to drive and reliable)
Hyundai Elantra or Sonata (great warranties and value)
Subaru Impreza (all-wheel drive for better handling)





Avoid flashy or expensive cars to reduce insurance costs.
Keep the car in good shape and maintain regular service to avoid breakdowns.
Consider safety accessories like backup cameras or parking sensors if possible.

Overall, the goal is a car that‚Äôs safe, reliable, not too expensive, and easy to drive for a new teen driver. This helps build good driving habits without extra stress or cost.

title: First Car Reccomendation
text:
Final Reflection
 Perplexity did a good job overall with the list, especially once I asked for the details like actual prices and safety ratings. At first, it gave me a solid general overview but didn‚Äôt provide the numbers or ratings upfront, which felt like a missing piece. I had to push a bit to get that kind of concrete info, so it wasn‚Äôt fully proactive in delivering everything at once. That said, Perplexity was quick and efficient at adapting when I asked for more specifics ‚Äî diving into real-time data sources, pulling current used car prices, and referencing reputable safety ratings from IIHS and NHTSA, which was impressive. The inclusion of citations made the info transparent and trustworthy, a big plus compared to other AI tools that often just throw out unchecked facts. Perplexity‚Äôs main strength is in combining web search and AI reasoning, so it can find accurate, up-to-date information and organize it well. But it doesn‚Äôt fully anticipate every detail users might want right away without some nudging. The conversation feel was pretty natural, and Perplexity stayed on topic, which made the process smooth.
